data.title: Robert Franklin Chandler Jr. (1927-2011)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Robert Chandler Jr. born 1927 Fort Worth, Tarrant, Texas, United States died 2011 Martha Jefferson Hospital, Charlottesville, Virginia, United States including ancestors + children + 1 genealogist comments + Y-chromosome DNA + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

[sibling(s) unknown]

Husband of [private wife (1940s - unknown)]

Father of [private son (1980s - unknown)]

Profile last modified 3 Sep 2023 | Created 17 Apr 2017

This page has been accessed 3,418 times.

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Early Life

1.2 Marriages and Family

1.3 Later Life and Death

2 Sources

Biography

Robert Chandler Jr. was an Alabamian.

Robert Chandler Jr. was born in Texas.

Robert Chandler Jr. lived in North Carolina

Robert Chandler Jr. lived in Virginia.

Early Life

Robert Franklin Chandler Jr. was a White male born on 4 September 1927[1][2][3][4] at 4:15pm in Fort Worth, Tarrant, Texas to Robert Franklin Chandler Sr. and Jean Holloman.[5][6][7][8][9][10] By 1930, he lived with his parents on 6th Street, Garland, Dallas, Texas.[11] He and his parents moved to 8 Nazarene Street, Sylacauga, Talladega, Alabama before 1935. By 1940, Robert Jr. lived with his parents at 8 Nazarene Street. He was listed as single, having attended school since 1 March 1940 and having completed elementary school, 6th grade.[12][13][14]

Robert attended Sylacauga High School starting around 1942 as a freshman.[15] He was also a member of the Glee Club in his high school.[16] Following high school, starting around 1946, Robert began attending Auburn University and pursuing a degree in aeronautical engineering.[17] By 1951, he changed his major to pursue a degree in electrical engineering.[18] During his time in college, he was a member of the Wesley Foundation, a Methodist religious group;[19] and Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia, a national music fraternity.[20][21] He graduated[22] from Auburn University[10] in 1952 with a degree in electrical engineering.[23]

Robert also served in the United States Army in the Signal Corp during the Korean War,[10] though it remains unclear if this occurred before or after his first marriage. He received a Navy an Marine Corps Achievement Medal on 1 October 1971 from the Commander Seventh Fleet for his service in Unit 01829.[24]

Marriages and Family

On 25 September 1956, Robert married his first wife Living Harley,[10] which was witnessed by Living Harley's father Percy W. Harley.[25][26] At this time, he lived with his father at 784 Arbor Road, Winston-Salem, Forsynth, North Carolina.[27] The couple later held a marriage ceremony on 29 September 1956 at Centenary Methodist Church, Winston-Salem, Forsyth, North Carolina.[8][28] He fathered two children with his first wife:

Living Chandler[10] in the 1960s[29]

Living Chandler[10] in the 1960s

On 28 June 1976, Robert filed for divorce from his wife Living Harley on grounds of a one-year separation. At this time, he lived separate from his wife and resided at 8112 Provincetown Drive, Richmond, Henrico, Virginia. The divorce was certified on 28 January 1980.[22]

On 7 June 1980, Robert married his second wife Living Weston.[10] He still lived at 8112 Provincetown Drive at this time. They held a marriage ceremony officiated by a Baptist minister.[9] They had one child together:

Living Chandler[10] in the 1980s

During his life, he worked as an engineer for General Electric.[10] He was named as an inventor on four known patents:

"Electrical terminal block" in 1959[30]

"Vehicle logging system" in 1969[31]

"Solid state circuits for and method of simulating relay logic" in 1973[32]

"Shot volume and cushion point control for injection molding apparatus" in 1975[33]

Later Life and Death

Toward the end of his life, he resided at 46 Branchland Court, Ruckersville, Greene, Virginia[1] and 6008 Partingdale Circle, Richmond, Henrico, Virginia.[2] In 1990, he hosted the 1990 WTJU Jazz Marathon.[34][35][36] Robert died on 6 September 2011[3] in Martha Jefferson Hospital, Charlottesville, Albemarle, Virginia.[10][37] He was buried at Monticello Memorial Park.[4]
